title: What are some good writing websites? - Quora

response.answer_text: 1. McGraw-Hill Story StructureRead this first. Yes, it’s long, but it contains everything you need to know about improving your writing skills. Pay particular attention to the sections on redundancy, cliches, word choices and nondiscriminatory words.  2. HemingwayDo not write another blog, social media or marketing post without putting it through the Hemingway App. The brainchild of writers Adam and Ben Long, this free algorithm color-codes your literary sins:Red denotes verbose, confusing passages.Yellow indicates hard to read sentences.Green points out the use of passive voice.Blue highlights adverbs, which the Papa despised.The app also assigns a reading level to your post.No download required! Hint: Delete the text that already appears on the page. Then, write or paste your own text.   3. Aztekera Passive Voice CheckerExamples of passive voice flood the world wide web, resulting in weak and non-persuasive writing. “To be” verbs, such as “is,” “was” and “were” exemplify passive verbs. Experiment, and see if you can cut most of these words. If you still use phrases such as “can be said to,” or “I was kissed by Johnny,” you need this app. Although worthwhile, this website has a distinct grammatical error. Can you find it?  4. Word CounterLook at your latest post. Do you keep repeating yourself, using the same words over and over again? If so, you’re just going through the motions of content writing. No sweat. Word Counter identifies word overuse. A varied vocabulary will improve your writing.   5. ThesaurusYour writing should paint a picture. The online Thesaurus serves as your writing paint brush. If theseoverused words dominate your writing, befriend this essential writing tool, before it’s too late.   6. Pro Writing AidUsing the distinctive features of Pro Writing Aid will improve your writing skills. The site provides the usual spelling and grammar tools, but adds a plagiarism checker and a vague and abstract words report. Use its sentence length variation tool to remove the monotony from your writing, and check the alliteration analyst to find words beginning with the same consonant. Like music and poetry, alliteration creates memorable prose. If the tool does not find any, substitute synonyms in some of your sentences.  7. Grammar Monster“Let’s eat grandma.” This sentence could give your poor grandmother a heart attack! Do you forget commas, or put them in the wrong place? Do hyphens and dashes drive you to drink? And what’s the scoop about ending a sentence with a preposition? The question brings to mind an old joke. A new Harvard student approaches a classmate, and asks him where the library is. The pedantic student replies, “In Harvard, we never end a sentence with a preposition.” The new student calmly rephrases his question: “Okay, do you know where the library is, moron?”  Who was correct? The Grammar Monster tells all.  8. Literary Devices to Improve Your Creative Writing StyleFreelancewriting.com created this free ebook, which adheres to the philosophy that “Style is that virtue in writing which makes it more than merely comprehensible.” The authors divided the book into four sections, which include control, structure, position and continuity.  9. Swipe Files for the Lazy CopywriterCreativity and enthusiasm often fail to ignite when we need it most, notes Helping Freelance Writers to Succeed since 1997. They created this free ebook for copywriters experiencing writers block. The swipe file provides an antidote to writer’s block. It consists of a set of templates or examples that you refer to when you begin a new project. This ebook includes swipe files for headlines, sub-headlines, calls to action and engaging questions.  10. GrammarlyMost content writers already know about Grammarly, which explains why we left it for last. The website discovers discovers grammatical errors that your writing program never finds. Examples include misuse of punctuation, prepositions and quantifiers. Grammarly offers a free trial, but the full site requires a paid membership. After the Deadline provides a similar service. Source: Ten Websites to Improve Your Writing Skills

I’ll recommend three free websites that I’ve tried and liked. They are 750 Words, Hemingway Editor and Slick Write. And I'll tell you about two books that will help you get over your grammatical superstitions. You can’t improve your writing until you have some writing to improve. To get started, try 750 Words. It’s a website run by Buster and Kellianne Benson. The first thirty days are free. After that you’re free to leave without subscribing if you don’t want to continue using it. The Bensons won’t bug you.  Among the things I liked about this site were the personal data visualizations. At the end of each session the site generates a chart. It tells you how many words you wrote, how long it took you to get to 750 words, how fast you typed and so on.  The site makes guesses about your feelings and concerns based on what you type, and charts them. It also makes guesses about your mindset, time orientation and other factors.  The site kept pegging sight as my primary sense. So I tested its algorithm by writing about tactile things. Lo and behold, it identified touch as my primary sense for that session. Hemingway Editor is another great site for improving your prose. I use TextWrangler, a free text editor from Bare Bones Software, for writing. So I write first and then copy and paste my stuff into Hemingway Editor. But a friend who uses Hemingway Editor prefers to write in the app itself. She then edits it according to the site's suggestions. Yellow highlights tell you when you’ve written hard-to-read sentences. Red highlights show you sentences that are even harder to read. Green identifies instances of passive voice. The site uses violet to highlight phrases with simpler alternatives. It uses blue to highlight adverbs. It’s not foolproof, mind you. Hemingway Editor misidentifies names ending in ly as adverbs. So Curtly, Twombly and Edgerly get blue highlights. Holly and Molly are kosher, but you get the finger-wagging routine for McNally. That’s about the only limitation I’ve encountered. Apart from that, it’s a good way to practice concise writing. Slick Write is, well, pretty slick. This is a deep, full-featured site. It lets you customize your settings for writing essays, fiction or whatever. And it helps you write clear and vivid sentences. When you paste your copy into Slick Write, it analyzes and critiques your prose. And it gives you lots of statistics. So you’ll know how many adjectives and adverbs you’ve used. Also how often you’ve lapsed into passive voice or used too many prepositional phrases. I first used Slick Write in November 2015, and didn’t like it. The site was set in a sans-serif font and there was no way to fix that. So I used the contact form and sent a note to the site owners suggesting they change the font to Georgia. I explained that serif fonts are easier to read since serifs aid horizontal eye movement. They also aid comprehension. That’s why newspapers are set in serif type. I added that designers who read know this and designers who don’t, don’t. Got an email from Craig Russell the next day saying he’d changed the site’s writing font to Georgia. Gosh that was quick, I thought, and thanked him. If you only have time to use one website to improve your style, I’d recommend Slick Write. It will help you master the art of readable writing. Get a copy of Theodore M. Bernstein’s Miss Thistlebottom’s Hobgoblins: The Careful Writer’s Guide to the Taboos, Bugbears and Outmoded Rules of English Usage. Also John R. Trimble’s Writing with Style: Conversations on the Art of Writing. These books will help you overcome your grammatical superstitions. Take serial commas, for example. Good writers use them when they feel they need them. The trouble started when someone said that the serial comma was once called the Oxford comma. Pedantry became the rage. Pretentious people started saying “Oxford comma” as if they had a lolly in their mouth. They even included the words “Oxford comma” in their Twitter profiles as a badge of erudition. I once dated a woman who read law at Magdalen College, Oxford. When I asked her about Oxford commas, she looked confused. When I explained what they were, she said, “Oh, you mean serial commas.” The thing is, punctuation is for pacing. Raymond Chandler understood that better than anybody before or since. That’s one of the reasons why he’s still a delight to read. Chandler knew he could speed up the pace of a sentence by skipping a comma. Here’s an example of how he did this (the line is from his short story The King in Yellow): I’m an occasional drinker, the kind of guy who goes out for a beer and wakes up in Singapore with a full beard. Some editors frown on using the serial comma only when it suits you. They cite the need for consistency. But as Emerson said, a foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds. Read a lot and write by ear. As a rule of thumb, if it sounds right, it probably is. If it isn’t, you can be sure some busybody will tell you about it. And then, since this is the Internet, you can always fix it.
